always performs her concerts barefoot in order to feel the vibrations of her instruments and the orchestra accompanying her. ==Health implications== [[File:(Left) (B) Adult foot that has never worn shoes, (Right) (A) Foot of a boy who has worn shoes for just a few weeks. Plaster casts.jpg|thumbnail|(Left–B) plaster cast of an adult foot that has never worn shoes displaying natural splayed toes (Right–A) cast of boy showing damage and inward-turned toes after wearing shoes for only a few weeks]] There are risks and benefits associated with going barefoot. Footwear provides some protection from puncture wounds from glass, nails, rocks, or thorns as well as abrasions, bruises, heat burns, electrical shock, and [[frostbite]]—but studies of people who habitually walk barefoot have consistently found that these problems are minimal, with only about 0.89% of barefoot people having any kind of foot complaint linked to walking barefoot (including temporary conditions such as abrasions) or having the tops of the feet uncovered.{{Citation needed|date=October 2014}} Feet that have never worn shoes rarely exhibit problems such as bunions, corns, and "[[Flat feet|fallen arches]]",{{cite journal |vauthors=Rao UB, Joseph B |title=The influence of footwear on the prevalence of flat foot. A survey of 2300 children |journal=J Bone Joint Surg Br |volume=74-B |issue=4 |pages=525–27 |date=July 1992 |pmid=1624509 |issn=0301-620X}}{{cite journal |vauthors=Sachithandam V, Joseph B |title=The influence of footwear on the prevalence of flat foot. A survey of 1846 mature persons |journal=J Bone Joint Surg Br |volume=77-B |issue=2 |pages=254–57 |date=March 1995 |pmid=7706341 |issn=0301-620X}} are not prone to more than ordinary foot eversion on standing and walking due to the associated weakness or stiffness of the joints of the foot and weakness of the muscles controlling them,{{cite journal |author=Hoffmann P |title=Conclusions drawn from a comparative study of the feet of barefooted and shoe-wearing peoples |journal=J Bone Joint Surg Am |volume=2 |issue=3 |pages=105–36 |date=October 1905 | url=http://bsmpg.com/Portals/52884/docs/1905Hoffman.pdf}} as well as having a much reduced incidence of problems such as callouses.{{cite journal|last=Zipfel|first=B.|author2=L.R. Berger|title=Shod versus unshod: The emergence of forefoot pathology in modern humans?|journal=The Foot|date=17 May 2007}} Walking barefoot results in a more natural gait. People who are used to walking barefoot tend to land less forcefully, eliminating the hard heel strike and generating much less collision force in the foot and lower leg.{{cite news|last=Sternbergh |first=Adam |title=You Walk Wrong. |url=http://nymag.com/health/features/46213/ |accessdate=June 26, 2010 |newspaper=New York Magazine |date=April 21, 2008 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080422191147/http://nymag.com/health/features/46213/ |archivedate=April 22, 2008 |deadurl=no }} A 2006 study found that shoes may increase stress on the knee and ankle, and suggested that adults who walked barefoot may have a lower rate of [[osteoarthritis]],{{cite journal |vauthors=Shakoor N, Block JA |title=Walking barefoot decreases loading on the lower extremity joints in knee osteoarthritis |journal=Arthritis Rheum. |volume=54 |issue=9 |pages=2923–27 |year=2006 |pmid=16947448 |doi=10.1002/art.22123 |ref=harv}} although more study is required to elucidate the factors that distribute loads in shod and barefoot walking. A 2007 study examined 180 modern humans and compared their feet with 2,000-year-old skeletons. They concluded that, before the invention of shoes, humans overall had healthier feet. A 1991 study found that children who wore shoes were three times more likely to have [[flat feet]] than those who did not, and suggested that wearing shoes in early childhood can be detrimental to the longitudinal arch of the foot. Children who habitually go barefoot were found to have stronger feet, with better flexibility and mobility, fewer deformities like flat feet or toes that curve inwards, and fewer complaints.{{cite news|last=Angier|first=Natalie|title=Which Shoes Are Best For Children? Maybe None.|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/14/news/which-shoes-are-best-for-children-maybe-none.html|accessdate=June 26, 2010|newspaper=The New York Times|date=August 14, 1991}} Walking barefoot enables a more natural gait, eliminating the hard heel strike and instead, allowing for a rocking motion of the foot from heel to toe. Similarly, barefoot running usually involves an initial forefoot strike, instead of on the rear of the foot, generating smaller collision forces. Since there is no artificial protection of the bare foot, some of the possible issues include cuts, abrasions, bruises, or puncture wounds from glass, nails, rocks, or thorns, as well as poisonous plants, animals, or [[parasite]]s that can enter the body through the cuts on an injured bare foot.{{cite journal |author=Staheli LT |title=Shoes for children: a review |journal=Pediatrics |volume=88 |issue=2 |pages=371–75 |year=1991 |pmid=1861942 |doi= |ref=harv}} In people who are not habitually barefoot, [[Athlete's foot]] is spread by fungal spores coming into contact with skin that has been weakened and made moist. The fungus is known to only affect around 0.75% of habitually barefoot people in one study and can be prevented by reducing shoe use and keeping the feet dry, particularly after walking through a damp environment where people communally walk barefoot as the fungus only develops under the right conditions, such as when people fail to properly dry their feet after swimming or showering and then put on shoes. Wearing shoes such as flip flops or sandals in these areas can reduce the risk.{{cite web|last=Hyde|first=Patricia|title=Athlete's Foot|url=http://kidshealth.org/kid/health_problems/skin/athletes_foot.html|publisher=kidshealth.org|accessdate=July 1, 2010}} As such, the fungus is very unlikely to develop on a person who goes barefoot all the time. The [[hookworm]] parasite, found only in warm, moist climates where human [[feces]] contaminated with hookworm larvae has been left in places where it might come into contact with human skin, can burrow through a bare human foot (or any part of the body that comes into contact with it).{{cite news|url=https://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/dpd/parasites/hookworm/factsht_hookworm.htm |title=Hookworm Infection |date=September 11, 2008 |publisher=[[Centers for Disease Control and Prevention]] |accessdate=August 4, 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20000301095412/http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/dpd/parasites/hookworm/factsht_hookworm.htm |archivedate=March 1, 2000 |deadurl=no }} However, as the parasite tends to occur mainly in mud and cesspools, its spread cannot be stopped by most standard shoes{{citation needed|date=September 2014}} since the larvae can penetrate fabric and small holes. The parasite may spread through contaminated material coming into contact with any part of the body, such as through flecks of mud splashing on an ankle or leg.{{cite journal|last=Trop|first=Am J|title=Penetration by Infective Hookworm Larvae of the Materials Used in the Manufacture of Shoes|url=http://www.ajtmh.org/content/s1-9/1/79.citation|accessdate=26 October 2012}}{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} The [[hookworm]] parasite is relatively mild, has few symptoms, and can pass completely unnoticed when the infestation level is low enough. Since the hookworm infection is very cheap and easy to treat, and since it requires infected feces to come into contact with human skin within a particular time period, eradicating hookworm is mainly a matter of hygiene (including the building of proper toilet and waste-disposal facilities) and mass-treatment. In very cold weather, shoes can provide thermal insulation, protecting against [[frostbite]]. Issues that can develop as a result of someone who has always worn shoes going barefoot include calf pain or [[Achilles tendinitis]] or [[plantar fasciitis]] due to shortening of the Achilles tendon and the foot being underdeveloped, due to regular use of shoes. A careful transition ease or remove symptoms, which quickly vanish as the foot adapts.{{cite web|last=Quinn|first=Elizabeth|title=Barefoot Running – The Pros and Cons of Going Shoeless|url=http://sportsmedicine.about.com/od/runningworkouts/a/Barefoot-Running.htm|publisher=About.com|accessdate=June 26, 2010}}{{cite book|last=Howell|first=Daniel|title=The Barefoot Book|year=2010|publisher=Hunter House|isbn= 978-1630266639}} Blisters on the feet may occur in the first few weeks of going barefoot, until the skin has become more robust. Individuals with [[diabetes]] or other conditions that affect sensation in the feet are at greater risk of injury while barefoot. The [[American Diabetes Association]] recommends that diabetics wear shoes and socks at all times.{{cite web|title=Foot Care. |url=http://www.diabetes.org/living-with-diabetes/complications/foot-complications/foot-care.html |publisher=[[American Diabetes Association]] |accessdate=June 26, 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111107213834/http://www.diabetes.org/living-with-diabetes/complications/foot-complications/foot-care.html |archivedate=November 7, 2011 |deadurl=no }} == Laws == In the United States, there have been myths that regulations require the wearing of footwear. In the United States, during the period of the [[Counterculture of the 1960s|counterculture movement of the 1960s]], business establishments would deny admittance to barefoot [[hippie]]s arguing that health regulations required that shoes be worn.{{cite news|url=http://www.newsobserver.com/105/story/1088537.html |title=Going barefoot |last=Miller |first=Joe |date=May 29, 2008 |work=[[The News and Observer]] |accessdate=August 5, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080602011040/http://www.newsobserver.com/105/story/1088537.html |archivedate=June 2, 2008 }} This led to a belief by many in nonexistent [[Occupational Safety and Health Administration|OSHA]] or local health department regulations preventing people from going to stores, restaurants, and other establishments without shoes. However, those regulations that exist apply only to employees and not customers.{{cite web|url=http://www.barefooters.org/osha.html |title=Bare Feet and OSHA |date=January 7, 2006 |publisher=barefooters.org |accessdate=August 5, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090524040917/http://barefooters.org/osha.html |archivedate=May 24, 2009 |df= }} Specifically, the United States [[Occupational Safety and Health Administration]] requires employers to "ensure that each affected employee uses protective footwear" when there is a danger of foot injuries due to falling or rolling objects, objects piercing the sole of an employee's foot, and where an employee's feet may be exposed to electrical hazards.{{cite news|last=Chow |first=Andrew |title=Is Going Barefoot at Work a Step Too Far? |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2012/05/02/tagblogsfindlawcom2012-freeenterprise-idUS286283164820120502 |accessdate=May 2, 2012 |newspaper=[[Reuters]] |date=May 2, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120508074700/http://www.reuters.com/article/2012/05/02/tagblogsfindlawcom2012-freeenterprise-idUS286283164820120502 |archivedate=May 8, 2012 |df= }} Additionally, employee footwear, where required by OSHA, must comply with one of the standards described in OSHA's regulations. State and local laws may dictate when and where an employee must wear shoes. Some people speculate that driving barefoot increases the risk of an accident if bare feet slip off the pedals.{{cite news|url=http://www.newsobserver.com/105/story/1088537.html |title=Legal myths, rumors about driving barefoot busted |last=Lawson |first=Alex |date=September 6, 2007 |work=[[The Daily Vidette]] |accessdate=August 5, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080602011040/http://www.newsobserver.com/105/story/1088537.html |archivedate=June 2, 2008 }} It is legal throughout the United States, Canada, and the United Kingdom to drive barefoot.{{cite web|url=http://www.barefooters.org/faq/18.html |title=Q18: Is it legal to drive barefoot? |date=July 13, 2004 |publisher=barefooters.org |accessdate=August 5, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090430105112/http://www.barefooters.org/faq/18.html |archivedate=April 30, 2009 |df= }}{{cite news|url=http://www.ocregister.com/articles/driving-california-shoes-2027147-vehicle-barefoot|title=HONK: The myth about driving barefoot|last=Hernandez|first=Salvador|date=April 25, 2008|work=|accessdate=August 5, 2009|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150907062322/http://www.ocregister.com/news/driving-181942-california-shoes.html|archive-date=2015-09-07|dead-url=yes|publisher=''[[The Orange County Register]]''}} However, in some US jurisdictions, police officers may ticket a driver for other things if the fact that they were driving barefoot or in [[flip-flops]]/high heeled shoes hindered their driving and/or resulted in an accident.{{cite web|url=http://www.barefooters.org/driving/index.html |title=Definitive Answer to Driving Barefoot in America |accessdate=15 February 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140222034855/http://www.barefooters.org/driving/index.html |archivedate=22 February 2014 |df= }} ==Sports and recreation== [[File:Blue leggings.jpg|thumb|right|A woman sitting in a library with her bare feet on a chair.]] There are several recreational activities one can participate in while barefoot. Those involved in [[water sports]] such as [[Swimming (sport)|swimming]] and [[water polo]] almost always participate barefoot due to the difficulty of swimming with footwear. Other common activities performed barefoot include yoga, pilates, [[hiking]], running, driving, water skiing, [[touch rugby]], [[soccer]], [[beach volleyball]], [[surfing]], [[tubing (recreation)|tubing]], [[gymnastics]], [[Slacklining]], and [[martial arts]]. [[Wrestling]] can be done barefoot. Although most modern [[Greco-Roman wrestling|Greco-Roman]] and [[World Wrestling Entertainment|WWE]] wrestlers wear shoes, [[sumo wrestling]], [[Yağlı güreş]] (oil or "Turkish" wrestling), and [[mud wrestling]] are commonly done while barefoot. [[Fiji]]an wrestler [[Jimmy Snuka|Jimmy "Superfly" Snuka]] of the WWE has wrestled barefoot as well.{{cite news|last=Traina |first=Jimmy |title=Favorite Wrestlers of All Time |url=http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/si_blogs/scorecard/jimmys_blog/2006/06/favorite-wrestlers-of-all-time.html |accessdate=July 10, 2010 |newspaper=[[Sports Illustrated]] |date=June 12, 2006 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080407185431/http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/si_blogs/scorecard/jimmys_blog/2006/06/favorite-wrestlers-of-all-time.html |archivedate=April 7, 2008 |df= }} [[American football]] is not traditionally a barefoot sport, though several [[placekicker]]s have preferred to kick barefoot, including [[Tony Franklin (kicker)|Tony Franklin]] of the [[Philadelphia Eagles]] and [[Rich Karlis]] of the [[Denver Broncos]].{{cite news|last=Gehman|first=Jim|title=Where Are They Now: PK Tony Franklin|url=http://www.philadelphiaeagles.com/news/Story.asp?story_id=12521|accessdate=June 27, 2010|newspaper=[[Philadelphia Eagles]]|date=May 5, 2007| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100619135621/http://www.philadelphiaeagles.com/news/Story.asp?story_id=12521| archivedate= 19 June 2010 | deadurl= no}}{{cite news|last=Moss|first=Irv|title=Karlis a standout as barefoot kicker|url=http://www.denverpost.com/ci_11559948?source=bb|accessdate=June 27, 2010|newspaper=[[Denver Post]]|date=January 27, 2009}} The two schools of thought involved in barefoot placekicking were that the lack of a shoe provided the kicker with a better "feel" for the ball and greater control over its trajectory. The second theory is that shoes and socks absorbed kinetic energy, and kicking flesh-to-leather created more [[torque]].{{cite news|last=Klosterman|first=Chuck|title=A brilliant idea! (For now)|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/espn/page2/story?page=klosterman/061016 |accessdate=June 27, 2010|newspaper=ESPN|date=October 16, 2006}} ===Hiking=== People of all ages all over the world can participate in barefoot hiking, gathering for walks through forest and hiking trails sans footwear. Barefoot hikers claim that they feel a sense of communion with the earth and enjoy the sheer pleasure of feeling more of the world with their feet.{{cite news|last=Todras-Whitehill|first=Ethan|title=Footloose and Boot Free: Barefoot Hiking.|url=http://travel.nytimes.com/2006/09/22/travel/escapes/22hike.html|accessdate=June 26, 2010|newspaper=The New York Times|date=September 22, 2006}} There are several clubs throughout North America practicing regular barefoot hikes, including the Barefoot Hikers of Minnesota, Seattle Barefoot Hikers, East Bay Barefoot Hikers, the Barefoot Hikers and Grass Walkers of Greater Kansas City, and the Barefoot Hikers of Connecticut.{{cite news|last=Pauly |first=Brett |title=Sole Survivors: New shoeless joes are hitting dusty trails around San Francisco Bay and beyond. |url=http://barefooters.org/hikers/publicity/la_daily_news.html |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/19961029205731/http://www.barefooters.org/hikers/publicity/la_daily_news.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=October 29, 1996 |accessdate=June 26, 2010 |newspaper=Los Angeles Daily News |date=March 21, 1996 }}{{cite web|title=Barefoot Hiking Groups|url=http://www.barefoothub.com/barefoot-hiking-groups/|website=The Barefoot Hub|accessdate=16 April 2015}} In this an [[analogy]] to the [[social state]] of former slaves was established, who were regularly forced to remain barefoot as well (see above).{{cite news|last=Lanza |first=Michael |title=The Happy Hoofers |url=http://barefooters.org/hikers/publicity/yankee.txt |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/19961029205838/http://www.barefooters.org/hikers/publicity/yankee.txt |dead-url=yes |archive-date=1996-10-29 |accessdate=June 26, 2010 |newspaper=Yankee Magazine |date=July 1995 }}{{cite news|title=In Conn. barefoot hiking club, tenderfoots welcome|url=http://www.courant.com/community/county-new-haven/hc-ap-ct-fea-barefoothikinjun19,0,5048908.story|accessdate=June 28, 2010|newspaper=Hartford Courant|date=June 20, 2010}}{{dead link|date=September 2016}} Two sisters, Lucy and Susan Letcher, hiked approximately two-thirds of the {{convert|2,175|mi|km|adj=on}} [[Appalachian Trail]] barefoot from June 21, 2000, to October 3, 2001.{{cite news|last=Belisle |first=Richard F. |title=Barefoot hikers return to Appalachian Trail for book tour |url=http://www.herald-mail.com/?cmd=displaystory&story_id=228195&format=html |accessdate=June 28, 2010 |newspaper=The Herald-Mail |date=August 5, 2009 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5hXOgrXpN?url=http://www.herald-mail.com/?cmd=displaystory |archivedate=June 15, 2009 |deadurl=no |df= }}{{cite book|title=The Barefoot Sisters: Southbound|year=2009|publisher=Stackpole Books|isbn=0-8117-3530-3|page=474|url=https://books.google.com/?id=_cFbPQAACAAJ&dq=barefoot+sisters|author8=Letcher, Lucy; Letcher, Susan}} On November 12, 2010, 2,500 people in [[Mahabubnagar]], [[India]], participated in a barefoot walk, which was recognized by ''[[Guinness World Records]]'' as the world's largest.{{cite web|title=Largest Barefoot Walk |url=http://www.guinnessworldrecords.com/world-records/8000/largest-barefoot-walk|publisher=[[Guinness World Records]] |accessdate=July 16, 2012}} In European nations, including Austria, Denmark, France, Germany, Hungary, Switzerland, and the United Kingdom, there are barefoot parks or walks.{{cite news|last=Owen|first=Wena Alun|title=Challenge senses on barefoot walk. |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/wales/north_west/7955356.stm|accessdate=June 26, 2010|newspaper=[[BBC News]]|date=March 20, 2009}}{{cite web|title=Public Barefoot Parks in Europe.|url=http://www.barfusspark.info/en/park.htm|publisher=barfusspark.info|accessdate=June 26, 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100605081950/http://www.barfusspark.info/en/park.htm| archivedate= 5 June 2010 | deadurl= no}} These parks are kept clean and maintained on a regular basis, so that barefoot hiking can be done in an environment suitable for people who are habitually shod. Barefoot parks usually include a lot of adventure stations, allowing visitors to experience the feeling of soil textures underfoot; to wade through rivers, mud, brooks, or ponds; and to exercise [[foot gymnastics]], [[Equilibrioception|balancing]], and climbing. The ''Barfußpfad'' (barefoot trail) at Bad Sobernheim in Germany attracts over 100,000 visitors annually and has seen approximately 1 million visitors since its inception in 1999.{{cite news|title=Fast eine Million Menschen.|url=http://www.allgemeine-zeitung.de/region/bad-kreuznach-bad-sobernheim-kirn/vg-bad-sobernheim/sobernheim/7927509.htm|accessdate=June 26, 2010|newspaper=Allgemeine Beitung |date=November 25, 2009|language=German}} This concept was first developed in the 19th century by [[Sebastian Kneipp]], one of the founders of the [[Naturopathy|Naturopathic medicine]] movement. He believed that applying your feet to a range of natural stimuli would have therapeutic benefits. This is related to the ancient practice of [[reflexology]], practiced in China for thousands of years for relaxation and to promote longevity.{{cite news|last=Wignall|first=Alice|title=Get your socks off|url=https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2008/mar/25/healthandwellbeing.walkingholidays|accessdate=July 1, 2010|newspaper=[[The Guardian]]|date=March 25, 2008}} [[Seoul]], South Korea, has 158 barefoot parks, allowing people to relax in a natural environment.{{cite news|title=158 barefoot parks in Seoul |url=http://english.seoul.go.kr/gtk/news/news_view.php?idx=413 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130218204705/http://english.seoul.go.kr/gtk/news/news_view.php?idx=413 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=February 18, 2013 |accessdate=June 26, 2010 |newspaper=seoul.go.kr |date=May 12, 2006 }} ===Running=== {{main|Barefoot running}} Many leisure and competitive runners have been known to run barefoot, including well-known athletes [[Zola Budd]] of South Africa and [[Abebe Bikila]] of [[Ethiopia]].{{cite journal|last=Warburton|first=Michael |title=Barefoot Running |journal=Sportscience|date=Sep–Dec 2001|volume=5|issue=3 |url=http://sportsci.org/jour/0103/mw.htm|accessdate=June 27, 2010 | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100722064341/http://www.sportsci.org/jour/0103/mw.htm| archivedate= 22 July 2010 | deadurl= no}} Todd Ragsdale, of [[Talent, Oregon]], set the world record (pending confirmation by ''[[Guinness World Records]]'') for the longest distance run barefoot on June 5, 2010, as part of the [[Relay for Life]] fundraiser for the [[American Cancer Society]]. He logged {{convert|102|mi|km}}, or 413 laps on the South Medford High School track, barefoot.{{cite news|last=Burke |first=Anita |title=Todd Ragsdale endures The agony of the feet |url=http://www.mailtribune.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20100608/NEWS/6080317/-1/NEWSMAP |accessdate=July 1, 2010 |newspaper=[[Mail Tribune]] |date=June 8, 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100610195008/http://www.mailtribune.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=%2F20100608%2FNEWS%2F6080317%2F-1%2FNEWSMAP |archivedate=10 June 2010 |deadurl=no }} The fastest person to run 100 meters (325 feet) on [[ice]] while barefoot is Nico Surings of [[Eindhoven]], Netherlands, who ran that distance in 17.35 seconds on December 8, 2006.{{cite web|title=Fastest run 100 metres barefoot on ice|url=http://www.guinnessworldrecords.com/records/amazing_feats/unusual_skills/Fastest_run_100_metres_barefoot_on_ice.aspx|publisher=[[Guinness World Records]]|accessdate=July 1, 2010}} Laboratory studies suggest that, due to the lack of extra weight on the feet, the energy cost of running barefoot is reduced by 4%, resulting in lower [[oxygen]] consumption. There is evidence that wearing traditional shoes while running leads to heel strike [[Gait (human)|gait]] that, in turn, leads to higher impact as well as a greater risk of injury. Barefoot running encourages the runner to switch to forefoot strike and may reduce the risk of knee damage. Barefoot running can be dangerous, especially to runners who do not adequately prepare or give their feet time to adapt to the new style. Many injuries are possible, such as injuries to the [[Achilles tendon]] or [[plantar fascia]], or [[stress fracture]]s in the [[metatarsal]] bones or lower leg. Barefoot runners who do not prepare their bodies could provide, "a stimulus plan for podiatrists, orthopedists, and physical therapists."{{cite news|last=Carey |first=Art |title=Well Being: Running barefoot has not-so-obvious hazards |url=http://www.philly.com/inquirer/magazine/20100628_Well_Being__Running_barefoot_has_not-so-obvious_hazards.html |accessdate=July 2, 2010|newspaper=[[Philadelphia Inquirer]]|date=June 28, 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100702011452/http://www.philly.com/inquirer/magazine/20100628_Well_Being__Running_barefoot_has_not-so-obvious_hazards.html| archivedate= 2 July 2010 | deadurl= no}} The official position on barefoot running by the [[American Podiatric Medical Association]] states that there is not enough research on the immediate- and long-term benefits of the practice and that individuals should consult a podiatrist with a strong background in sports medicine to make an informed decision on all aspects of their running and training programs.{{cite web|title=APMA Position Statement on Barefoot Running|url=http://www.apma.org/Media/position.cfm?ItemNumber=995|publisher=[[American Podiatric Medical Association]]|accessdate=November 4, 2010}} One alternative to barefoot running is to wear thin-soled shoes with minimal padding, such as [[moccasin]]s, [[plimsolls]], or [[huarache (running shoe)|huaraches]], which result in similar gait to going barefoot but protect the skin and keep dirt and water off.{{cite news|last=Hersher|first=Rebecca|title=Perfect Landing. |url=http://alumni.harvard.edu/stories/perfect-landing |accessdate=June 26, 2010|newspaper=[[Harvard University]]|date=January 27, 2010}} Some modern shoe manufacturers have recently designed footwear to maintain optimum flexibility while providing a minimum amount of protection. Such shoes include the shoes made by [[Vibram FiveFingers]],{{cite news |title=Vibram FiveFingers Named A "Best Invention of 2007" by Time Magazine. |url=http://www.trailspace.com/articles/2007/11/12/vibram-fivefingers-named-a-best-invention-of-2007-by-time-magazine.html |accessdate=June 26, 2010|newspaper=trailspace.com|date=November 12, 2007}}{{cite web|last=Gauthier|first=Al|title=Review – Vibram FiveFingers KSO Trek.|url=http://www.livingbarefoot.info/2010/05/review-vibram-fivefingers-kso-trek/|publisher=Living Barefoot|accessdate=June 26, 2010|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100619133712/http://www.livingbarefoot.info/2010/05/review-vibram-fivefingers-kso-trek/#|archivedate=2010-06-19|deadurl=yes|df=}} [[Vivobarefoot]],{{cite news |last=Woollard|first=Deirdre|title=EVO Shoes Offer A Close-To-The-Earth Experience |url=http://www.luxist.com/2010/03/13/evo-shoes-offer-a-close-to-the-earth-experience/|accessdate=July 1, 2010|newspaper=Luxist|date=March 13, 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100525125928/http://www.luxist.com/2010/03/13/evo-shoes-offer-a-close-to-the-earth-experience/| archivedate= 25 May 2010 | deadurl= no}} and [[Nike, Inc.|Nike]]'s [[Nike Free]] shoes.{{cite news|last=Cortese|first=Amy|title=Wiggling Their Toes at the Shoe Giants |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/08/30/business/30shoe.html |accessdate=July 1, 2010|newspaper=[[New York Times]]|date=August 29, 2009}} Sales of minimalist running shoes have grown into a [[United States Dollar|$]]1.7 billion industry. Sales of Vibram FiveFingers alone grew from $450,000 in 2006 to $50 million in 2011.{{cite news|last=Mirshak |first=Meg|title=Minimalist-style shoes mimic running barefoot.|url=http://chronicle.augusta.com/life/2012-07-19/minimalist-style-shoes-mimic-running-barefoot|accessdate=July 22, 2012|newspaper=[[Augusta Chronicle]]|date=July 19, 2012}} ===Water skiing=== [[File:DylanBarefoot2.jpg|thumb|upright|A barefoot skier]] {{main|Barefoot skiing}} Barefoot skiing originated in [[Winter Haven, Florida]], in 1947, when slalom skier A.G. Hancock tried to step off his ski.{{cite book|last=Oleksy|first=Walter G.|title=Barefoot Waterskiing|year=2000|publisher=Capstone Books |isbn=0-7368-0480-3|pages=13–15|url=https://books.google.com/?id=QTYtMJwJ4VcC&printsec=frontcover&q}} The same year, in [[Cypress Gardens, Florida]], competitive skier Richard Downing Pope, Jr., became well known in the sport of barefoot skiing.{{cite web|title=Richard Downing Pope, Jr.|url=http://www.waterskihalloffame.com/docs/Bios/Richard%20Pope%20Jr.htm|publisher=Water Ski Hall of Fame|accessdate=June 27, 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100619162517/http://waterskihalloffame.com/docs/Bios/Richard%20Pope%20Jr.htm| archivedate= 19 June 2010 | deadurl= no}} The first barefoot skiing competition was held three years later, at the 1950 Cypress Gardens Dixie Championships.{{cite news|last=Poyet |first=Philippe |title=The History of Barefooting |url=http://barefoot.org/index2.php?option=com_content&do_pdf=1&id=21 |accessdate=June 27, 2010 |newspaper=American Barefoot Waterski Club |date=May 13, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101027201933/http://barefoot.org/index2.php?option=com_content&do_pdf=1&id=21 |archivedate=October 27, 2010 |df= }} In 1978, skiers from ten nations competed in the first World Barefoot Championships in [[Canberra]], Australia. The same year, the American Barefoot Club (ABC) was formed, which governs competitive barefoot skiing events in the United States. ===Skateboarding=== Early skateboarders rode barefoot, preferring foot-to-board contact and emulating surfing moves.{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=NxembYuScL8C&redir_esc=y |title=The Skateboard: The Good, the Rad, and the Gnarly: An Illustrated History |author=Ben Marcus |publisher=Books.google.com.au |date= |accessdate=2015-11-27}}[https://books.google.com/books?id=vWWWfp_22DQC&pg=PA33&lpg=PA3&dq=skateboarder+gary+swanson&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q=skateboarder%20gary%20swanson&f=false Skateboarding, Space and the City: Architecture and the Body] By Iain Borden. Goggle Books.{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=O5dvdvyuTOkC&pg=PA21&redir_esc=y |title=The Answer is Never: A Skateboarder's History of the World |author=Jocko Weyland |publisher=Books.google.com.au |date= |accessdate=2015-11-27}} The plastic [[penny board]] is intended to be ridden barefoot, and Penny Skateboards have promoted the riding of the board barefoot by selling T-shirts and stickers.{{cite web|url=http://www.pennyskateboards.com/eu/bare-foot-is-back.html |title=penny stickers |publisher=Pennyskateboards.com |date= |accessdate=2015-11-27}}{{cite web|url=http://www.pennyskateboards.com/eu/penny-bare-foot-shirt.html|title=Blue Bare Foot Shirt|last=|first=|date=|website=pennyskateboards.com|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150613213305/http://www.pennyskateboards.com/eu/penny-bare-foot-shirt.html#|archivedate=2015-06-13|deadurl=yes|accessdate=August 23, 2017|df=}} They have also posted social media posts encouraging barefoot riding,{{cite web|url=https://instagram.com/p/3QaR_EmTx6/ |title=Instagram |publisher=Instagram |date= |accessdate=2015-11-27}}{{cite web|url=https://instagram.com/p/vkaJL8mTy5/ |title=Instagram |publisher=Instagram |date= |accessdate=2015-11-27}} particularly in summer.{{cite web|url=https://instagram.com/p/yY3qS1mTwX/ |title=Instagram |publisher=Instagram |date= |accessdate=2015-11-27}} The [[Hamboard]], a surfboard style board, is also intended to be ridden barefoot. Barefoot skateboarding has been witnessing a revival in recent times.{{cite web|url=http://blahfilmproject.tumblr.com/ |title=BLAHskateboards: filmproject |publisher=Blahfilmproject.tumblr.com |date= |accessdate=2015-11-27}} Many modern skateboarders skate barefoot, especially in summer and in warmer countries like [[Australia]], [[South Africa]], and parts of [[South America]]. ==See also== {{Div col}} * [[Shoe#Antiquity|Shoe]] * [[Ötzi#Clothes and shoes|Ötzi]] * [[Barefoot doctor]] * [[Barefoot in the Park (film)|''Barefoot in the Park'' (film)]] * [[Colton Harris-Moore]] (also known as the "Barefoot Bandit") {{Div col end}} {{clear}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{Sister project links|barefoot}} * {{Commons-inline|Barefoot park}} {{nudity}} [[Category:Barefoot| ]] [[Category:Foot]] [[Category:Human appearance]]

{{Infobox artwork | image_file = Hildesheim-Christussaeule-Hildesia.jpg | caption = The Bernward Column in Hildesheim Cathedral (1893–2009) | image_size = 260px | title = Bernward Column | italic title=no | year = {{circa|1000}} | type = [[victory column]] | material = [[bronze]] | height_metric = 3.79 | diameter_metric = 0.58 | metric_unit = m | city = [[Hildesheim]] }} [[File:Hildesheim-Christussaeule-Rekonstruktionszeichnung.png|thumb|upright|The Bernward Column in [[St. Michael's Church, Hildesheim|St. Michael's]] (before 1810). Reconstruction by Carpiceci/Gallistl]] [[File:Hildesheim Christussaeule 1810-1893.jpg|thumb|upright|The Bernward Column in the Domhof (1810–1893)]] [[File:Hildesheim-Dom-Bernwardssaeule 01a.JPG|thumb|upright|The column in the cathedral, with the [[Hezilo chandelier]] in the background]] [[File:Christussäule 2009-09-30.jpg|thumb|upright|Welcoming the Berward Column to St. Michael's, 30 September 2009]] The '''Bernward Column''' ({{lang-de|Bernwardssäule}}) also known as the '''Christ Column''' ({{lang-de|Christussäule}}) is a [[Romanesque art|Romanesque]] bronze column, made {{circa|1000}} for [[St. Michael's Church, Hildesheim|St. Michael's Church]] in [[Hildesheim]], Germany, and regarded as a masterpiece of [[Ottonian art]]. It was commissioned by [[Bernward of Hildesheim|Bernward]], thirteenth bishop of Hildesheim. It depicts images from the life of [[Jesus]], arranged in a helix similar to [[Trajan's Column]]: it was originally topped with a cross or [[crucifix]]. During the 19th century, it was moved to a courtyard and later to [[Hildesheim Cathedral]]. During the restoration of the cathedral from 2010 to 2014, it was moved back to its original location in St. Michael's, but was returned to the Cathedral in August 2014. == Original location and history == The Bernward Column was made for [[St. Michael's Church, Hildesheim]], the foundation and final resting place of Bishop Bernward. It initially stood in the east choir, behind the altar, with a triumphal cross. This location under the triumphal arch was proposed by Gallistl using the literary sourcesLit. Gallistl (1993) p. 32 and confirmed in 2006 by excavations."Grabungszeichnung Harenberg", in Christiane Segers-Glocke (ed.), ''St. Michael in Hildesheim: Forschungsergebnisse zur bauarchäologischen Untersuchung im Jahr 2006'', CW Niemeyer Buchverlage GmbH, Hameln 2008, Copyright: 2008 [[Niedersächsisches Landesamt für Denkmalpflege]] (= Arbeitshefte zur Denkmalpflege in Niedersachsen 34) {{ISBN|978-3-8271-8034-6}}: S. 153 In addition, a copper-coated marble column stood in front of the altar, whose stone came from the eastern Mediterranean and, according to later sources, was a gift from [[Holy Roman Emperor|Emperor]] [[Otto III, Holy Roman Emperor|Otto III]] to Bernward. The altar was equated with the offering table in the forehall of the [[Temple of Solomon]], which also stood between two columns ([[Boaz and Jachin]]).e.g. Gallistl, ''Der Dom zu Hildesheim und sein Weltkulturerbe, Bernwardstür und Christussäule'', pp. 30-31 A large [[wheel chandelier]], which was meant to have been a gift from Otto III to Bernward, hung above the Bernward Column until 1662, with a porphyry jug in the centre that was claimed to derive from the [[Wedding at Cana]]. This arrangement of a column topped with a cross, an altar and a wheel chandelier was modelled on the [[Church of the Holy Sepulchre]], which was also equated with the fore hall of the Temple of Solomon. Furthermore, the distance of roughly {{convert|42|m}} between the original location of the column and the grave of Bernward in the west crypt of St. Michael's matched the distance between the Rotunda of the Resurrection and [[Golgotha]] in the Church of the Holy Sepulchre, according to the reports of pilgrims.Hartwig Beseler, Hans Roggenkamp. ''Die Michaeliskirche in Hildesheim.'' Berlin 1954. p. 102 In 1544, during the chaos of the [[Reformation]] in Hildesheim, the cross on top of the column was removed by iconoclasts. It was melted down and recast as a cannon, suggesting that it was of considerable size. After the demolition of the east choir of St. Michael's in 1650 and the resulting collapse of the east [[crossing (architecture)|crossing]], the column's [[capital (architecture)|capital]], which "weighed about a hundred pounds", was also melted down and replaced by a wooden capital of identical shape and size, meant to hide the replacement. An engraving by Johann Ludwig Brandes (1730) indicates that it was decorated with figures. Since figural capitals of this kind are otherwise only attested from the twelfth century, it has been suggested that the capital that was melted down was not the Bernwardian original either, and that this original was replaced during the renovation of the cloister church in the second half of the twelfth century.Lit. Olchawa (2008) S. 70 ff The rest of the column was not melted down in the following years (despite its value as raw material) because of its ancient significance as a [[contact relic]], since it was believed to have been made personally by St. Bernward. In 1810, after the [[German mediatization|secularisation]] of the Catholic cloister (1803) and the abolition of the Protestant parish of St. Michael's (1810), the column was removed on the private initiative of diocese officials and installed in the north of the [[Domhof, Hildesheim|Domhof]] between the cathedral and the Bishop's house. In 1870 the Hildesheim sculptor [[Karl Küsthardt]] gave the column a new bronze capital, which was meant to imitate the wooden capital or an illustration of it and to indirectly preserve the appearance of the old bronze capital, which had supported an [[Impost (architecture)|impost]] topped by a bronze crucifix. In 1893 it was moved into the cathedral. On 30 September 2009 it was moved back to St. Michael's for the duration of the cathedral renovations, which lasted until August 2014.[http://www.dom-hildesheim.de/en/content/ancient-world-heritage-new-light "ANCIENT WORLD HERITAGE IN A NEW LIGHT"] == Description == The Bernward column, which is {{convert|3.79|m}} high and {{convert|58|cm}} in diameter, is a [[Victory column]] that Bernward had cast from bronze in conscious imitation of the marble [[Trajan's Column]] and the [[Column of Marcus Aurelius]] in [[Rome]]. Just as those stone columns depict the military deeds of the Emperor in an upward spiralling frieze, so the Bernward column depicts the peaceful deeds of Christ, beginning with his [[Baptism of Jesus|baptism]] at the [[Jordan]] and ending with his [[triumphal entry into Jerusalem]]. The column was originally crowned with a [[triumphal cross]].[http://www.domsanierung.de/de/bernwards%C3%A4ule-christuss%C3%A4ule Bernwardsäule (Christussäule)] domsanierung.de {{de icon}}[http://www.alfred-ehrhardt-stiftung.de/index.php?alfred-ehrhardt-the-bernward-column-of-hildesheim-photography-and-film-1964 Alfred Ehrhardt: The Bernward Column of Hildesheim. / Photography and film 1964]''[https://books.google.com/books?id=GXS0AAAAQBAJ&pg=PA14 Medieval Treasures from Hildesheim]'' Yale University Press, 2013 The column is significant for the vitality of the figural relief, which is unusual for the time. The relief complements the [[Bernward Doors]], which picture the [[Nativity of Jesus|Nativity]], [[Passion (Christianity)|Passion]], and [[resurrection]] of Jesus. Both artworks, like the rest of Bernward's artistic and architectural programme, reflect his efforts to put his seat in the position of a northern Rome in the context of the [[Ottonian dynasty]]'s renewed Christian Roman Empire and also to emphasise Christ as a model of just and godly kingship for the rulers. For this reason, the execution of [[John the Baptist]] by the weak and unjust king [[Herod Antipas]] is given a great deal of space. File:Christussäule 5.jpg|

({{Bibleverse|Mt|21|1-11}}, {{Bibleverse|Mk|11|1-11}}, {{Bibleverse|Lk|19|28-40}}, {{bibleverse|John|12|12-19}})
== Liturgical significance == An important indicator of the liturgical significance of the Bernward column is its original location on the central axis of St. Michael's near the altar since that is where communion was distributed and the sacrament was stored. In the reliefs the importance of the gospels on [[Palm Sunday]] is emphasised, which might be connected with the [[Cluniac reforms]].Olchawa 2008. S. 95 The references to the Lenten and penitential rites, which are also found in the imagery of the Bernward Doors, support this.Bernhard Gallistl, "In Faciem Angelici Templi. Kultgeschichtliche Bemerkungen zu Inschrift und ursprünglicher Platzierung der Bernwardstür." ''Jahrbuch für Geschichte und Kunst im Bistum Hildesheim'' 75/76 (2007/2008) p. 84 n. 26 == Cast == Since 1874 there has been a [[plaster cast]] of the column in the [[Victoria and Albert Museum]] in [[London]], bought for £18 from one F. Künsthardt.{{cite web|url=http://www.vam.ac.uk/users/node/15500|title=Scenes from the Life of Christ|last=Victoria and Albert Museum|date=2012|work=The Cast Court Collection|publisher=Victoria and Albert Museum|accessdate=18 June 2014}} == Bibliography == * Heinz Josef Adamski, Hermann Wehmeyer: ''Die Christussaule im Dom zu Hildesheim'', Hildesheim 1979 * Michael Brandt, Arne Eggebrecht (ed.): ''Bernward von Hildesheim und das Zeitalter der Ottonen, Katalog der Ausstellung 1993.'' vol. [[File:Bezantee moulding style, 1914 Encyclopaedia Britannica.png|thumb|right|200px|Bezantée moulding style, showing the use of the disc like forms as a decoration for a Romanesque pier and arcade]] '''Bezantée''', '''bezantie''' or '''bezanty''' is an ornamentation consisting of [[roundel]]s. The word derives from ''[[bezant]]'', a [[gold]] [[coin]] from the [[Byzantine Empire]], which was in common European use until circa 1250.
In architecture, '''bezantée''' moulding was much used in the Norman period.<ref>{{Cite EB1911 |wstitle=Bezantée |volume=3 |page=840}}</ref>
In [[heraldry]] the word is shorthand for ''semé of bezants'', i.e. strewn (literally "seeded") with bezants. A bezant is a [[roundel (heraldry)|roundel]] whose [[tincture (heraldry)|tincture]] is ''[[Or (heraldry)|or]]''. In English heraldry, a field ''sable bezanty'' often alludes to the [[Duchy of Cornwall]]. An ounce (leopard) bezanty appears as a supporter in the English bearings of [http://www.civicheraldry.co.uk/east_anglia_essex.html St Edmundsbury Borough Council]; a bordure bezanty appears in the coat of [http://www.civicheraldry.co.uk/thames_valley_chilterns.html Berkhamstead Town Council].

'''Burning in Water gallery''' is a contemporary art gallery located in Chelsea, New York City.
Artists represented by Burning in Water include [[Valerie Hegarty]], Jessie Krimes, and Borinquen Gallo.
Originally opened as an innovative curatorial project space in 2016, the gallery has since become a primary market gallery.
Past notable exhibitions include Hegarty's ''American Berserk'',<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://events.umich.edu/event/43941|title=American Berserk exhibition by Valerie Hegarty {{!}} Happening @ Michigan|website=events.umich.edu|language=en|access-date=2017-11-09}}</ref> Krimes' ''Marking Time in America'', and Gallo's ''Like a Jungle Orchid for a Lovestruck Bee''.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://news.artnet.com/art-world/new-york-fall-gallery-show-preview-1005836|title=Here Are 51 New York Gallery Shows That You Need to (Somehow) See This September {{!}} artnet News|date=2017-09-07|work=artnet News|access-date=2017-11-09|language=en-US}}</ref>

{{Infobox ancient site |name = Burqush |native_name =برقش |alternate_name = Burkush, Barkousa, Justinianopolis, Barkousa-Justinianopolis |image = |alt = |caption = |map_type = Syria |map_alt = 1580 |map_size = 200 |location = {{convert|30|km|mi}} west of [[Damascus]] |region = [[Rif Dimashq Governorate]] |coordinates = {{coord|33.466667|35.983333|display=inline}} |type = |part_of = |length = |width = |area = |height = |builder = |material = |built = |abandoned = |epochs = |cultures = [[Byzantine]], [[Ancient Rome|Roman]] |dependency_of = |occupants = |event = |excavations = 1999 |archaeologists = Gunnar Brands |condition = Ruins |ownership = |management = |public_access = Yes |website = |notes = }} '''Burqush''' or '''Burkush''' ({{lang-ar|برقش}}) is an archaeological site situated {{convert|30|km|mi}} west of [[Damascus]], [[Syria]].<ref name="BeattiePepper2001">{{cite book|author1=Andrew Beattie|author2=Timothy Pepper|title=The Rough Guide to Syria|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=9iCfkTe8v2EC&pg=RA1-PA16|accessdate=21 September 2012|date=1 July 2001|publisher=Rough Guides|isbn=978-1-85828-718-8|pages=1–}}</ref><ref name="RuprechtsbergerErtel1994">{{cite book|author1=Erwin Maria Ruprechtsberger|author2=Christine Ertel|title=Vom Mount Hermon zum Djebel Burqush|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=0KkKMAEACAAJ|accessdate=21 September 2012|year=1994|publisher=Stadtmuseum Linz}}</ref>
The nearby [[Wadi al-Qarn – Burqush Important Bird Area|Wadi al-Qarn]] is an important breeding site for wild [[bird]]s in the [[Middle East]] and has been identified by [[BirdLife International]] as an [[Important Bird Area]].<ref name="EvansEast1994">{{cite book |author1=M. I. Evans |title=Important bird areas in the Middle East|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=iZrwAAAAMAAJ|accessdate=21 September 2012|year=1994|publisher=BirdLife International|isbn=978-0-946888-28-3}}</ref>
The site sits at an [[altitude]] of {{convert|1580|m|ft}} and overlooks the [[Damascus]] plain and surrounding hill country where herds of [[goat]]s and [[camel]]s wander the area. Due to the sensitive nature of the territory close to the borders with [[Lebanon]] and the [[Golan]], visitors may need a military escort to access the site, which is a ten-minute walk along a steep track away from the main road.<ref name="BeattiePepper2001"/>
Julien Aliquot suggested that the site may have been called '''Barkousa''' in ancient times. This was contrary to the location of '''Barkusha''' that had previously been suggested by [[Albrecht Alt]] in 1947.<ref name="Kaizer2008">{{cite book|author=Ted Kaizer|title=The Variety of Local Religious Life in the Near East In the Hellenistic and Roman Periods|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=KgVD3WL0vAsC&pg=PA90|accessdate=21 September 2012|year=2008|publisher=BRILL|isbn=978-90-04-16735-3|pages=90–}}</ref> In the 6th century, it was renamed '''Justinianopolis''' ({{lang-el|Ἰουστινιανούπολις}}, "city of Justinian") after the [[Byzantine Empire|Byzantine]] emperor [[Justinian I]].<ref>[http://www.homepages.ucl.ac.uk/~tcrnadk/Lovell_2011.pdf Klein, Konstantin., Review of Aliquot, J., Inscriptions Grecques et Latines de la Syrie - Tome 11: Mount Hermon (Liban et Syrie) Beirut: Presses de l'IFPO (Bibliothèque archéologique et historique 183) Reviews, Levant, Vol 43, No 1, 2011.]</ref><ref name="Potts2012">{{cite book|author=D. T. Potts|title=A Companion to the Archaeology of the Ancient Near East|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=zqQofdcZAGoC&pg=PA1070|accessdate=21 September 2012|date=27 April 2012|publisher=John Wiley & Sons|isbn=978-1-4443-6076-9|pages=1070–}}</ref>
==Byzantine basilica and Roman temple== There are the ruins of two [[Roman temple]]s in the village that are included in a group of [[Temples of Mount Hermon]].<ref name="Kaizer20082">{{cite book|author=Ted Kaizer|title=Aliquot, Julien., Sanctuaries and villages on Mount Hermon in the Roman period in The Variety of Local Religious Life in the Near East In the Hellenistic and Roman Periods|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=KgVD3WL0vAsC&pg=PA76|accessdate=17 September 2012|year=2008|publisher=BRILL|isbn=978-90-04-16735-3|pages=76–}}</ref><ref name="Dar1993">{{cite book|author=Shimʻon Dar|title=Settlements and cult sites on Mount Hermon, Israel: Ituraean culture in the Hellenistic and Roman periods|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=tuwtAQAAIAAJ|accessdate=21 September 2012|year=1993|publisher=Tempus Reparatum|isbn=978-0-86054-756-3}}</ref>
The ruins of a 6th-century CE [[Byzantine empire|Byzantine]] [[basilica]] lie on the top of a hill which has been artificially flattened to form a two level plateau. The area around features numerous rock cut rooms and crypts. The podium on which the basilica is constructed is suggested to be that of a previous [[Roman temple]] suggested to date to the 1st century CE. The Roman temple itself is thought to have been built on the remains of a previous temple that had been in use for secular purposes for at least four hundred years earlier and possibly for many generations prior. The basilica is constructed of massive blocks of stone and the site is littered with other confusing blocks, some of which possibly resemble buildings or unusual [[geological]] outcrops.<ref name="BeattiePepper2001"/>
The temple complex at Burqush was mentioned by the [[Germany|German]] archaeological mission to [[Baalbek]] in 1903 and has received little study since then. A [[topographic]] and architectural survey of the site was conducted in 1999 by Gunnar Brands for the [[University of Halle-Wittenberg]]. A dissertation covering the results of the survey is in progress by Frederike von Bargen.<ref name="brands">[http://www.orientarch.uni-halle.de/digs/burqush/burqush.htm Burqush (Syria) - Archaeological Survey 1999, Funded by the German Research Foundation, Director: Prof. Dr. Gunnar Brands, Martin-Luther-Universität Halle-Wittenberg Institut für Altertumswissenschaften, Seminar für Orientalische Archäologie und Kunstgeschichte]</ref><ref>von Bargen, Friederike., Die Kirchenanlage von Burqush im Hermongebirge und ihre Ausstattung, Institut für Orientalische Archäologie und Kunst (in progress)</ref>
The survey noted complex substructures, and intended to document the surrounding settlements, [[tomb]]s, [[quarries]] and a [[propylon]] temple ruins. The survey was hampered by the remoteness and altitude of the site, tank shelling, and finding a settlement in the area that was twice as large as expected with numerous rock cut tombs nearby. The basement of the basilica was constructed from bedrock and showed a high technical quality of construction. Traces of bronze [[candle]] holders were found along with remnants of a [[marble]] cover that was white with gray veining. Twelve [[capital (architecture)|capitals]] were recorded in 1903, of which only eight remained in place, with three more displaced nearby, one reused for [[medieval]] farming. The twelfth capital had been covered in rubble and totally obscured. The east wall of the basilica features a [[portico]]. Foundations of what were thought to be a [[peristyle]] for the basilica were found to its north west, some of the area to the north was cleared and leveled by the military.<ref name="brands"/> The remains of the settlement are dispersed on the east slope of the hill are also large buildings on the west slope.<ref name="Kaizer2008"/>

{{primary sources|date=February 2015}} The '''City Chamber Orchestra of Hong Kong''' was founded in [[Hong Kong]] in 1999. The chief conductor is [[Jean Thorel]], who has held the post since 2008.
==Background== The CCOHK was founded in 1999 by oboist Leanne Nicholls, who is also the artistic director.<ref>[http://ccohk.com/administration.htm List of administration in the orchestra] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090505203501/http://www.ccohk.com/administration.htm |date=2009-05-05 }}</ref> It is known for having a very large repertoire spanning many different styles.<ref>[http://www.bcmagazine.net/hk.bcmagazine.issues/bcmagazine_webissue256/03-ccohk.html Magazine article in the ''BC Magazine''] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080531124215/http://bcmagazine.net/hk.bcmagazine.issues/bcmagazine_webissue256/03-ccohk.html |date=2008-05-31 }}</ref> Jean Thorel, the chief conductor, was appointed in 2008. Previous guest conductors include [[German Guiterrez]], [[Carlos Checa (musician)|Carlos Checa]], [[Andrew Sewell]], [[Anthony Inglis (conductor)|Anthony Inglis]], [[Andrew Massey (musician)|Andrew Massey]], [[Philip Walsh]], [[Nicholas Routley]], [[Peter Leech]], [[Bill Connor (musician)|Bill Conner]], [[Richard Honner]], [[Richard Harvey]], [[Lorenzo Colitto]] (guest concertmaster), [[Francis Kan]], [[Veiga Jardim]], and [[David Gwilt]].
==See also== * [[Hong Kong Philharmonic Orchestra]] * [[Hong Kong Sinfonietta]] * [[Hong Kong Chamber Orchestra]] * [[Pan Asia Symphony Orchestra]]

{{Infobox coat of arms | name = The Arms of Yukon | image = Coat of arms of Yukon.svg | image_width = 150 | middle = Badge of the Commissioner of Yukon.svg | middle_width = 100 | middle_caption = Badge of the [[Commissioner of Yukon|Commissioner]] | lesser = | lesser_width = | lesser_caption = | armiger = [[Yukon]] | year_adopted = 1956 | crest = Alaskan Malamute standing on a mound of snow | torse = | shield = | supporters = | helm = | compartment = | motto = | orders = | other_elements = | earlier_versions = | use = }}
The '''coat of arms of Yukon''' is the [[heraldic symbol]] representing the Canadian territory of [[Yukon]]. The arms was commissioned by the federal [[Department of Indian Affairs and Northern Development]] and designed by well-known heraldry expert [[Alan Beddoe]] in the early 1950s. It was officially approved by Queen [[Elizabeth II]] in 1956.
The lower part of the shield represents Yukon's mountains,<ref name="cansymbols">{{cite web|url=http://www.pch.gc.ca/progs/cpsc-ccsp/sc-cs/symboles-histoire-symbols-stories/symbole_canada_symbols-eng.pdf|title=Symbols of Canada|year=2008|publisher=Canadian Heritage|accessdate=20 November 2008|page=42}}</ref> with the gold disks (called "[[bezants]]," a medieval gold coin) representing the territory's mineral resources and its birth in the [[Klondike Gold Rush]]. The two white wavy lines represents the territory's rivers.
In chief, the red cross represents England,<ref name="cansymbols"/> the disk surmounting it is in a pattern called "vair," a type of [[heraldic fur]] (literally squirrel fur), and representing the territory's wealth of fur-bearing animals.
The crest is an [[Alaskan Malamute]] dog standing on a mound of snow.
==Blazon== Shield: ''Azure, on a pallet wavy Argent, a like pallet of the field, issuant from base two piles reversed Gules, fimbriated also Argent, each charged with two bezants in pale, on a chief Argent a cross Gules, surmounted of a roundel vair.''
Crest: ''On a wreath Or and Gules, standing on a mound of snow Proper, an Alaskan Malamute statant Proper.''
==See also== *[[Symbols of Yukon]] *[[Flag of Yukon]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=May 2012}} {{Use British English|date=May 2012}} {{Infobox film | name = Cry Freedom | image = Cry Freedom.jpg | caption = Theatrical release poster | alt = | director = [[Richard Attenborough]] | producer = Richard Attenborough | screenplay = [[John Madera]] | starring = {{Plainlist| * [[Kevin Kline]] * [[Penelope Wilton]] * [[Denzel Washington]] }} | music = [[George Fenton]]
[[Jonas Gwangwa]] | cinematography = [[Ronnie Taylor]] | editing = [[Lesley Walker]] | studio = Marble Arch Productions | distributor = [[Universal Pictures]] | released = {{Film date|1987|11|6|United States|1987|11|26|United Kingdom}} | runtime = 157 minutes | country = United Kingdom
South Africa | language = English
Afrikaans
Xhosa
Zulu | budget = $29 million | gross = $5.9 million{{cite web |url=http://boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=cryfreedom.htm |title=Cry Freedom |publisher=[[Box Office Mojo]] |accessdate=2010-06-15}} }} '''''Cry Freedom''''' is a 1987 British-South African epic drama film directed by [[Richard Attenborough]], set in late-1970s [[apartheid]] era [[South Africa]]. The screenplay was written by [[John Briley]] based on a pair of books by journalist [[Donald Woods]]. The film centres on the real-life events involving black activist [[Steve Biko]] and his friend Donald Woods, who initially finds him destructive, and attempts to understand his way of life. [[Denzel Washington]] stars as Biko, while actor [[Kevin Kline]] portrays Woods. ''Cry Freedom'' delves into the ideas of discrimination, political corruption, and the repercussions of violence. The film was primarily shot on location in [[Zimbabwe]] and in [[Kenya]] due to political turmoil in South Africa at the time of production. As a film showing mostly in limited cinematic release, it was nominated for multiple awards, including Academy Award nominations for Best Actor in a Supporting Role, Best Original Score, and Best Original Song. It also won a number of awards including those from the Berlin International Film Festival and the British Academy Film Awards. A joint collective effort to commit to the film's production was made by [[Universal Pictures]] and Marble Arch Productions. It was commercially distributed by Universal Pictures cinematically, and by [[MCA Home Video]] for home media. ''Cry Freedom'' premiered in cinemas nationwide in the United States on 6 November 1987 grossing $5,899,797 in domestic ticket receipts. The film was at its widest release showing in 479 cinemas nationwide. It was generally met with positive critical reviews before its initial screening in cinemas. South African authorities unexpectedly allowed the film to be screened in cinemas without cuts or restrictions, despite the publication of Biko's writings being banned at the time of its release.https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/28/world/pretoria-censors-to-let-cry-freedom-be-seen.html ==Plot== Following a news story depicting the demolition of a slum in [[East London, Eastern Cape|East London]], [[South Africa]], liberal journalist [[Donald Woods]] (Kevin Kline) seeks more information about the incident and ventures off to meet black activist [[Steve Biko]] (Denzel Washington). Biko has been officially [[banning order|''banned'']] by the [[South African government]] and is not permitted to leave his defined banning area at [[King William's Town]]. Woods is formally against Biko's banning, but remains critical of his political views. Biko invites Woods to visit a black township to see the impoverished conditions and to witness the effect of the government-imposed restrictions, which make up the apartheid system. Woods begins to agree with Biko's desire for a South Africa where blacks have the same opportunities and freedoms as those enjoyed by the white population. As Woods comes to understand Biko's point of view, a friendship slowly develops between them. After speaking at a gathering of black South Africans outside of his banishment zone, Biko is arrested and interrogated by South African security forces. Following this, he is brought to court in order to explain his message directed toward the South African government. After he speaks eloquently in court and advocates non-violence, the security officers who interrogated him visit his church and vandalize the property. Woods assures Biko that he will meet with a government official to discuss the matter. Woods then meets with [[Jimmy Kruger]] ([[John Thaw]]), the South African Minister of Justice in his house in [[Pretoria]] in an attempt to prevent further abuse by the security force. Kruger first expresses discontent over the actions of security force, however Woods is later harassed by security forces at his home. The security men that harass Woods insinuate that their orders to visit Woods came directly from Kruger. Later, Biko decides to travel to Cape Town to speak at a student-run meeting. En route, security forces stop his car and arrest him. He is held in harsh conditions and beaten, causing a severe brain injury. A doctor recommends consulting a nearby specialist in order to best treat his injuries, but the police refuse out of fear that he might escape. The security forces instead decide to take him to a police hospital in Pretoria, around 700 miles (1 020 km) away from Cape Town. He is thrown into the back of a prison van and driven on a bumpy road, aggravating his brain injury and resulting in his death. Woods then works to expose the police's complicity in Biko's death. He attempts to expose photographs of Biko's body that contradict police reports that he died of a hunger strike, but he is prevented just before boarding a plane to leave and informed that he is now banned, therefore not able to leave the country. Woods and his family are targeted in a campaign of harassment by the security police. He later decides to seek asylum in England to expose the corrupt and racist nature of the South African authorities. After a long trek, Woods is eventually able to escape to the Kingdom of [[Lesotho]], disguised as a priest. His wife Wendy ([[Penelope Wilton]]) and their family later join him. With the aid of Australian journalist [[Bruce Haigh]] ([[John Hargreaves (actor)|John Hargreaves]]), the [[British High Commission]] in Maseru, and the [[Government of Lesotho]], they are flown under [[United Nations Laissez-Passer|United Nations passports]] and with one Lesotho official over South African territory, via [[Botswana]] to [[London]], where they were granted [[political asylum]]. The film's epilogue displays a graphic detailing a long list of anti-apartheid activists (including Biko), who died under suspicious circumstances while imprisoned by the government. == Cast == {{div col}} * [[Denzel Washington]] as [[Steve Biko]] * [[Kevin Kline]] as [[Donald Woods]] * [[Penelope Wilton]] as Wendy Woods * [[Alec McCowen]] as British Acting High Commissioner * [[Kevin McNally]] as Ken * [[Ian Richardson]] as State Prosecutor * [[John Thaw]] as [[Jimmy Kruger]] * [[Timothy West]] as Capt. de Wet * [[Josette Simon]] as Dr. [[Mamphela Ramphele]] * [[John Hargreaves (actor)|John Hargreaves]] as [[Bruce Haigh]] * [[Miles Anderson]] as Lemick * [[Zakes Mokae]] as Father Kani * [[John Matshikiza]] as Mapetla {{div col end}} ==Production== ===Development=== [[File:South Africa racial map, 1979.gif|thumb|right|350px|Racial-demographic map of South Africa in the late 1970s.]] The premise of ''Cry Freedom'' is based on the true story of [[Steve Biko]], the charismatic South African [[Black Consciousness Movement]] leader who attempts to bring awareness to the injustice of [[Apartheid]]; and [[Donald Woods]], the [[Liberalism in South Africa|liberal]] white editor of the ''[[Daily Dispatch]]'' newspaper who struggles to do the same after Biko is murdered. In 1972, Biko was one of the founders of the [[Black People's Convention]] working on social upliftment projects around Durban.{{cite web |url=http://africanhistory.about.com/od/stevebiko/a/bio-Biko.htm |title=Stephen Bantu (Steve) Biko |publisher=About.com |accessdate=2010-06-20}} The BPC brought together almost 70 different black consciousness groups and associations, such as the South African Student's Movement (SASM), which played a significant role in the 1976 uprisings, and the Black Workers Project which supported black workers whose unions were not recognized under the Apartheid regime. Biko's political activities eventually drew the attention of the South African government which often harassed, arrested, and detained him. These situations resulted in his being banned in 1973. The banning restricted Biko from talking to more than one person at a time, in an attempt to suppress the rising anti-apartheid political movement. Following a violation of his banning, Biko was arrested and later killed while in police custody. The circumstances leading to Biko's death caused worldwide anger, as he became a martyr and symbol of black resistance. As a result, the South African government banned a number of individuals (including Donald Woods) and organizations, especially those closely associated with Biko. The United Nations Security Council responded swiftly to the killing by later imposing an arms embargo against South Africa. After a period of routine harassment against his family by the authorities, as well as fearing for his life, Woods fled the country after being placed under house arrest by the South African government.[http://news.bbc.co.uk/onthisday/hi/dates/stories/january/1/newsid_2459000/2459845.stm 1978: Newspaper editor flees South Africa]. [[BBC]]. Retrieved 20 June 2010. Woods later wrote a book in 1978 entitled: ''[[Biko (book)|Biko]]'', exposing police complicity in his death. That book, along with Woods's autobiography ''Asking For Trouble'', both being published in the UK, became the basis for the film.{{cite web |url=http://www.sahistory.org.za/pages/people/bios/biko-s.htm |title=Stephen Bantu Biko |publisher=South African History Online |accessdate=2010-06-15}} ===Filming=== Principal filming took place primarily in the Republic of [[Zimbabwe]] because of the tense political situation in South Africa at the time of shooting. Other filming locations included [[Kenya]], as well as film studios in [[Shepperton, England|Shepperton]] and [[Middlesex, England]].[[Richard Attenborough|Attenborough, Richard]] (Director). (1987). ''Cry Freedom'' [Motion picture]. United States: [[Universal Pictures]]. The film includes a dramatized depiction of the [[Soweto uprising]] which occurred on 16 June 1976. Indiscriminate firing by police killed and injured hundreds of African schoolchildren during a protest march. ===Music=== The original motion picture soundtrack for ''Cry Freedom'' was released by [[MCA Records]] on 25 October 1990.{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.com/dp/B000002O5E |title=Cry Freedom: Original Motion Picture Soundtrack |accessdate=2010-06-15 |publisher=Amazon}} It features songs composed by veteran musicians [[George Fenton]], [[Jonas Gwangwa]] and Thuli Dumakude. At Biko's funeral they sing the hymn [[Nkosi Sikelel' iAfrika]]. Jonathan Bates edited the film's music.{{cite web|url=https://movies.yahoo.com/movie/1800052312/cast |title=Cry Freedom |accessdate=2010-06-15 |publisher=Yahoo! Movies}} A live version of [[Peter Gabriel]]'s 1980 song "[[Biko (song)|Biko]]" was released to promote the film; although the song was not on the film soundtrack, footage was used in its [[music video|video]].{{cite book|last=Bowman|first=Durrell|title=Experiencing Peter Gabriel: A Listener's Companion|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=_o8BDQAAQBAJ&pg=PA93|accessdate=12 September 2017|date=2016-09-02|publisher=Rowman & Littlefield Publishers|isbn=9781442252004|page=93}} ==Reception== ===Critical response=== Among mainstream critics in the U.S., the film received mostly positive reviews. [[Rotten Tomatoes]] reported that 82% of 22 sampled critics gave the film a positive review, with an average score of 6.5 out of 10.[http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/cry_freedom/ Cry Freedom (1987)]. [[Rotten Tomatoes]]. IGN Entertainment. Retrieved 2010-06-15. {|class="toccolours" style="float: left; margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 2em; font-size: 85%; background:#FFFFE0; color:black; width:25em; max-width: 70%;" cellspacing="5" |style="text-align: left;"|"It can be admired for its sheer scale. Most of all, it can be appreciated for what it tries to communicate about heroism, loyalty and leadership, about the horrors of apartheid, about the martyrdom of a rare man." |- |style="text-align: left;"|—Janet Maslin, writing in ''The New York Times''Maslin, Janet (6 November 1987). [https://movies.nytimes.com/movie/review?res=9B0DE6D61239F935A35752C1A961948260 Cry Freedom]. ''[[The New York Times]]''. Retrieved 2010-06-15. |} Rita Kempley, writing in ''[[The Washington Post]]'', said actor Washington gave a "zealous, Oscar-caliber performance as this African messiah, who was recognized as one of South Africa's major political voices when he was only 25."Kempley, Rita (6 November 1987). [https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-srv/style/longterm/movies/videos/cryfreedompgkempley_a0ca3d.htm Cry Freedom]. ''[[The Washington Post]]''. Retrieved 2010-06-15. Also writing for ''The Washington Post'', [[Desson Howe]] thought the film "could have reached further" and felt the story centring on Woods's character was "its major flaw". He saw director Attenborough's aims as "more academic and political than dramatic". Overall, he expressed his disappointment by exclaiming, "In a country busier than Chile with oppression, violence and subjugation, the story of Woods' slow awakening is certainly not the most exciting, or revealing."Howe, Desson (6 November 1987). [https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-srv/style/longterm/movies/videos/cryfreedompghowe_a0b116.htm Cry Freedom]. ''[[The Washington Post]]''. Retrieved 2010-06-15. [[Roger Ebert]] in the ''[[Chicago Sun-Times]]'' offered a mixed review calling it a "sincere and valuable movie" while also exclaiming, "Interesting things were happening, the performances were good and it is always absorbing to see how other people live." But on a negative front, he noted how the film "promises to be an honest account of the turmoil in South Africa but turns into a routine cliff-hanger about the editor's flight across the border. It's sort of a liberal yuppie version of that [[Night Crossing|Disney movie]] where the brave East German family builds a hot-air balloon and floats to freedom."Ebert, Roger (6 November 1987). [http://rogerebert.suntimes.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/19871106/REVIEWS/711060301/1023 Cry Freedom]. ''[[Chicago Sun-Times]]''. Retrieved 2010-06-15. [[Janet Maslin]] writing in ''[[The New York Times]]'' saw the film as "bewildering at some points and ineffectual at others" but pointed out that "it isn't dull. Its frankly grandiose style is transporting in its way, as is the story itself, even in this watered-down form." She also complimented the African scenery, noting that "''Cry Freedom'' can also be admired for Ronnie Taylor's picturesque cinematography". The ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety Staff]]'', felt Washington did "a remarkable job of transforming himself into the articulate and mesmerizing black nationalist leader, whose refusal to keep silent led to his death in police custody and a subsequent coverup." On Kline's performance, they noticed how his "low-key screen presence served him well in his portrayal of the strong-willed but even-tempered journalist."Variety Staff (1 January 1987). [http://www.variety.com/review/VE1117790168.html?categoryid=31&cs=1 Cry Freedom]. ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]''. Retrieved 2010-06-15. Film critic [[Gene Siskel]] of the ''[[Chicago Tribune]]'' gave the film a ''thumbs up'' review calling it "fresh" and a "solid adventure" while commenting "its images do remain in the mind ... I admire this film very much." He thought both Washington's and Kline's portrayals were "effective" and "quite good".Siskel, Gene (6 November 1987). [http://bventertainment.go.com/tv/buenavista/atm/reviews.html?sec=1&subsec=2008 Cry Freedom]{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}. ''[[At the Movies (1986 TV program)|At the Movies]]''. Retrieved 2010-06-15. Similarly, Michael Price writing in the ''[[Fort Worth Press]]'' viewed ''Cry Freedom'' as often "harrowing and naturalistic but ultimately self-important in its indictment of police-state politics."Price, Michael (6 November 1987). Cry Freedom. ''[[Fort Worth Press]]''. Retrieved 2010-06-15. {|class="toccolours" style="float: right; margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 2em; font-size: 85%; background:#FFFFE0; color:black; width:40em; max-width: 80%;" cellspacing="5" |style="text-align: left;"|"Attenborough tries to rally with Biko flashbacks and a depiction of the Soweto massacre. But the 1976 slaughter of black schoolchildren is chronologically and dramatically out of place. And the flashbacks only remind you of whom you'd rather be watching." |- |style="text-align: left;"|—Desson Howe, writing for ''The Washington Post'' |} Mark Salisbury of ''[[Time Out (magazine)|TimeOut]]'' boasted on the film's merits by declaring the lead acting to be "excellent" and the crowd scenes "astonishing", while equally observing how the climax was "truly nerve-wracking". He called it "an implacable work of authority and compassion, ''Cry Freedom'' is political cinema at its best."Salisbury, Mark (6 November 1987). [http://www.timeout.com/film/reviews/69923/cry_freedom.html Cry Freedom] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110607001440/http://www.timeout.com/film/reviews/69923/cry_freedom.html |date=7 June 2011 }}. ''[[Time Out (company)|TimeOut]]''. Retrieved 2010-06-15. James Sanford however, writing for the ''[[Kalamazoo Gazette]]'', did not appreciate the film's enduring qualities, calling it "a Hollywood whitewashing of a potentially explosive story."Sanford, James (6 November 1987). Cry Freedom. ''[[Kalamazoo Gazette]]''. Retrieved 2010-06-15. Rating the film with ''3 Stars'', critic [[Leonard Maltin]] wrote that the film was a "Sweeping and compassionate film". He did however note that the film "loses momentum as it spends too much time on Kline and his family's escape from South Africa". But in positive followup, he pointed out that it "cannily injects flashbacks of Biko to steer it back on course."Maltin, Leonard (5 August 2008). ''Leonard Maltin's 2009 Movie Guide''. Signet. p. 301. {{ISBN|978-0-452-28978-9}}. In 2013, the movie was one of several discussed by [[David Sirota]] in ''[[Salon.com]]'' in an article concerning [[White savior narrative in film|white savior narratives in film]].{{cite news | last=Sirota | first=David | url=http://www.salon.com/2013/02/21/oscar_loves_a_white_savior/ | title=Oscar loves a white savior | work=[[Salon.com]] | date=February 21, 2013 | accessdate=May 14, 2014 }} ===Accolades=== The film was nominated and won several awards in 1987–88.{{cite web|url=http://movies.msn.com/movies/movie-awards-and-nominations/cry-freedom.1/?ipp=30 |title=Cry Freedom: Awards & Nominations |accessdate=2010-06-15 |publisher=MSN Movies}}{{cite web|url=https://movies.yahoo.com/movie/1800052312/awards |title=Cry Freedom (1987) |accessdate=2010-06-15 |publisher=Yahoo! Nominated{{cite web|url=http://www.afi.com/Docs/100Years/cheers300.pdf |title=AFI's 100 Years...100 Cheers Nominees |format=PDF |date= |accessdate=2016-08-14}} ===Box office=== The film premiered in cinemas on 6 November 1987 in limited release throughout the U.S. During its opening weekend, the film opened in a distant 19th place and grossed $318,723 in business showing at 27 cinemas.{{cite web |url=http://www.the-numbers.com/movies/1987/0CRFR.php |title=Cry Freedom |publisher=The Numbers |accessdate=2010-06-15}} The film ''[[Fatal Attraction]]'' opened in first place with $7,089,680 screening at 1,351 theaters. The film's revenue dropped by 10.6% in its second week of release, earning $284,853. For that particular weekend, the film fell to 25th place showing in 19 cinemas. The film ''[[The Running Man (1987 film)|The Running Man]]'' unseated ''Fatal Attraction'' to open in first place with $8,117,465 in box office revenue showing at 1,692 cinemas. ''Cry Freedom'' had one week in wider release beginning with the 19–21 February weekend in 1988.{{cite web |url=http://boxofficemojo.com/weekend/chart/?view=&yr=1988&wknd=08&p=.htm |title=Weekend Box Office Results for November 19–21, 1988 |publisher=[[Box Office Mojo]] |accessdate=2010-06-15}} The film opened in 14th place showing at 479 cinemas grossing $802,235 in box office business. The film went on to top out domestically at $5,899,797 in total ticket sales through a 4-week cinematic run. For 1987 as a whole, the film would cumulatively rank at a box office performance position of 103. ===Home media=== Following its cinematic release in the late 1980s, the film was released to television in a [[Broadcast syndication|syndicated]] two night broadcast. Extra footage was added to the film to fill out the block of time. The film was later released in [[VHS]] video format on 5 May 1998.{{cite web |url=https://www.amazon.com/dp/B00005LO61 |title=Cry Freedom VHS Format |publisher=[[Amazon.com]] |accessdate=2010-06-15}} The [[DVD region code|Region 1 Code]] [[widescreen]] edition of the film was released on [[DVD-Video|DVD]] in the United States on 23 February 1999. Special features for the DVD include; production notes, cast and filmmakers' biographies, film highlights, web links, and the theatrical cinematic.{{cite web |url=http://movies.msn.com/movies/movie-on-dvd/cry-freedom.1/ |title=Cry Freedom: On DVD |publisher=MSN Movies |accessdate=2010-06-15}} Currently, there is no scheduled release date set for a future [[Blu-ray]] Disc version of the film, although it is available in other media formats such as [[Video on demand]].{{cite web |url=https://www.amazon.com/dp/B000I9VOA8 |title=Cry Freedom: VOD Format |publisher=Amazon.com |accessdate=2010-09-06}} ==See also== {{Portal|Film}} * [[1987 in film]] * [[English-language accents in film#South African|English-language accents in film – South African]] ==Bibliography== * {{cite book | last=Biko | first=Steve | title=Steve Biko: Black Consciousness in South Africa; Biko's Last Public Statement and Political Testament | year=1979 | publisher=Random House | isbn=978-0-394-72739-4 }} * {{cite book | last=Biko | first=Steve | title=I Write What I Like: Selected Writings | year=2002 | publisher=University of Chicago Press | isbn=978-0-226-04897-0 }} * {{cite book | editor1-last=Clarke | editor1-first=Anthony J.| editor2-last=Fiddes | editor2-first=Paul S.| title=Flickering Images: Theology and Film in Dialogue | series = Regent's Study Guides | volume = 12 | year=2005 | publisher=Smyth & Helwys Publishing | location = Macon, GA |isbn=1-57312-458-3 }} * {{cite book | last=Goodwin | first=June | title=Heart of Whiteness: Afrikaners Face Black Rule In the New South Africa | year=1995 | publisher=Scribner | isbn=978-0-684-81365-3 }} * {{cite book | last=Harlan | first=Judith | title=Mamphela Ramphele | year=2000 | publisher=The Feminist Press at CUNY | isbn=978-1-55861-226-6 }} * {{cite book | last=Juckes | first=Tim | title=Opposition in South Africa: The Leadership of Z.
