The '''Symphony''' by the American composer [[Steven Stucky]] is a four-movement [[symphony]] for [[orchestra]]. The work was jointly commissioned by the [[New York Philharmonic]] and the [[Los Angeles Philharmonic]]. It was composed from January through July 2012 and premiered September 28, 2012 at the [[Walt Disney Concert Hall]] in [[Los Angeles]], with [[conducting|conductor]] [[Gustavo Dudamel]] leading the Los Angeles Philharmonic.<ref>{{cite web |title='Symphony' by Steven Stucky |work=[[Los Angeles Times]] |date=September 26, 2012 |url=http://articles.latimes.com/2012/sep/26/entertainment/la-et-steven-stucky-box-20120926 |accessdate=April 4, 2015}}</ref><ref name="LATimes">{{cite web |last=Ng |first=David |title=Steven Stucky marks return to L.A. with his very own 'Symphony' |work=[[Los Angeles Times]] |date=September 26, 2012 |url=http://articles.latimes.com/2012/sep/26/entertainment/la-et-cm-steven-stucky-20120926 |accessdate=April 4, 2015}}</ref> The work had its [[New York City]] premiere November 29, 2012, with [[Alan Gilbert (conductor)|Alan Gilbert]] leading the New York Philharmonic.<ref name="NYTimes">{{cite web |last=Tommasini |first=Anthony |authorlink=Anthony Tommasini |title=A New Work Bares Its Secrets, With Feeling |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=November 30, 2012 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/12/01/arts/music/new-york-philharmonic-plays-steven-stuckys-symphony.html |accessdate=April 4, 2015}}</ref>
==Composition== The symphony has a duration of approximately twenty minutes and is composed in four connected [[Movement (music)|movements]]: #Introduction and Hymn #Outcry #Flying #Hymn and Reconciliation
Stucky had previously written four other symphonies, but has since withdrawn all of them, saying, "I wrote two when I was a little boy, and I have no idea what unholy mash-up those were. Then I wrote a symphony when I was a senior in college, and then one for my doctoral thesis, and I'm sure those have been completely expunged from the record." He therefore remarked "It was not sensible to call this piece Symphony No. 5" and elected to simply title the new work "Symphony."<ref name="LATimes" /> Stucky also described the piece as "old fashioned" and said, "It has recognizable themes which come back. That links it to the traditional form."<ref>{{cite web |last=Oksenhorn |first=Stewart |title=Music Festival: A new start for new music in Aspen |work=[[The Aspen Times]] |date=July 21, 2013 |url=http://www.aspentimes.com/news/7360687-113/music-stucky-aspen-program |accessdate=April 4, 2015}}</ref> The work is dedicated to the flutist [[Mimi Stillman]].<ref name="Program">{{cite web |title=Alan Gilbert and the New York Philharmonic: New York Philharmonic 2012–13 Season |work=[[New York Philharmonic]] |year=2013 |url=http://nyphil.org/~/media/pdfs/watch-listen/commercial-recordings/1213/release08.pdf |accessdate=April 3, 2015}}</ref>
==Reception== Reviewing the New York City premiere, [[Anthony Tommasini]] of ''[[The New York Times]]'' praised the accessibility of the Symphony and called it "a fairly modest piece, a 20-minute, colorfully orchestrated work in four parts, played without break." Despite giving the piece an overall positive review, Tommasini nevertheless opined, "Mr. Stucky perhaps achieved his goal of writing a graspable symphony too well. I was engrossed in the work right through, and Mr. Gilbert drew an exciting performance from the orchestra. But the music may give away its secrets too readily."<ref name="NYTimes" />

{{Infobox artwork|image=Kugelspieler_by_Georg_Christian_Freund_2.jpg|caption=The Berlin cast.|title=The Bowls Player|artist=Georg Christian Freund|medium=Bronze sculpture|year=1857}} '''''The Bowls Player''''' is an 1857 bronze statue by the Danish sculptor [[Georg Christian Freund]]. It is a modern adaptation of classical sculptures of athletes such as [[Polykleitos]]'s ''[[Doryphoros]]'' and [[Myron]]'s ''[[Discobolus]]''.
The plaster model for the work and the first casting from it were lost in the fire which destroyed the [[Christiansborg Palace]] in Copenhagen in 1884. Three other casts are known to survive: *[[Ny Carlsberg Glyptotek]], Copenhagen *[[National Gallery of Denmark]], Copenhagen *[[Alte Nationalgalerie]], Berlin - previously owned by the archaeologist [[Theodor Wiegand]] and now on long-term loan to his house in [[Berlin-Dahlem]], where it is displayed on the terrace as it was during Wiegand's lifetime

page.title: The Continuing Story of Carel and Ferd

revision.text:
{{italic title}} <!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:Continuing.jpg|thumbnail|alt=Continuing alt text|Still from '''The Continuing Story of Carel and Ferd ''' taken from vdb.org]] --> '''''The Continuing Story of Carel and Ferd'' ''' is a [[video]] directed by Arthur Ginsberg and Video Free America involving footage filmed between 1970 and 1975 following the lives and marriage of Carel Rowe and Ferd Eggan. Originally shown as a 3- channel video, 8-monitor installation including live feed of the audience for [[The Kitchen]] in New York in 1971,<ref>Debbie Gould. http://areachicago.org/ferd-eggan-1946-2007/, Area Chicago: Ferd Eggan 1946-2007</ref> the edited video is now distributed by [[Video Data Bank]] and [[Electronic Arts Intermix]]. The edited video consists of an hour-long tape selected from over 30 hours of footage that includes both the footage of the marriage and subsequent consummation, shot from 1971- 1972, and footage of an interview of Carel, Ferd, and Ginsberg produced for [[WNET]]'s Video and Television Review in 1975. The video is most readily available as a 33:15 segment on a collection of videos and video segments produced by Video Data Bank, ''Surveying the First Decade: Volume One: Program 3: Approaching Narrative: "There are Problems to be Solved"''.<ref>http://www.vdb.org/titles/continuing-story-carel-and-ferd-excerpt Video Data Bank, The Continuing story of Carel and Ferd</ref>''The Continuing Story of Carel and Ferd'' is often classified as video vérité, somewhere in between [[cinéma vérité]] and [[reality television]], though the footage predates [[An American Family]], often considered the first example of reality television.<ref>http://www.eai.org/title.htm?id=2957 Electronic Arts Intermix, The Continuing story of Carel and Ferd</ref>
''The Continuing Story of Carel and Ferd'' blends modes of camera address, featuring shots taken by Ginsberg of the couple in private or among friends, as well as first-person camera confessional shots.<ref>Renov, Michael. "Video Confessions." The Subject of Documentary. Minneapolis: U of Minnesota, 2004. 201-02.</ref> Ginsberg, through the recently founded Video Free America, received some of the first Sony [[Portapak]]s in America in order to shoot the footage.<ref>Gary Indiana. http://www.poz.com/articles/221_1548.shtml. POZ, Inside Agitator</ref> Seeking to film the making of a pornographic film, Ginsberg found Carel and Ferd, who were looking to make an erotic film from their wedding, in order to repay a man whose car Ferd had recently crashed. Ginsberg began shooting the day that Richard, an old friend of Carels, came by to talk about the wedding. This initial session was spontaneous, and in this instance Ginsberg says that in using video media, he was able to capture this footage impulsively, the video came about by chance. Though the footage is centered on the event of the wedding, the camera's insertion into the lives of Carel and Ferd before the event means that much of the footage anticipates the wedding self-consciously.<ref name="Phillips_98_101">Phillips, Glenn. "Arthur Ginsberg and Video Free America." California Video: Artists and Histories. Los Angeles: Getty Research Institute, 2008. 98-101.</ref> Though the footage is cut to highlight specific moments and events, most of the footage is edited straightforwardly so as to not interrupt the narrative flow, the limited editing testament to Ginsberg's belief that with videotape any editing at all is "sapping its strength as a real-time medium."<ref name="Phillips_98_101"/>
==Synopsis == ''The Continuing Story of Carol and Ferd'' takes on a loose long-form narrative, with two main subjects in a circle of friends, primarily shot in San Francisco. Carel Rowe, a filmmaker and erotic film actress and Ferd Eggan, a queer junkie, seek to be married, in part for the "media show" of their marriage and in part, a genuine desire to express their love for one another through the legal union of marriage. The footage features several others in their social group, notably Richard, a previous paramour of Carel's, who appears in an attempt to convince Carel and Ferd to not get married, as well as in the actual marriage scene. The video also features several unnamed friends, often present and sometimes addressed during the filming. Both Carel and Ferd also mention many others in their circle, including Ferd's alleged lovers, a source of contention between the two. On camera, the two kiss, interrogate one another, banter, argue, and have sex. The camera documents their intimacy as well as interrupts it, as they address the camera directly and answer questions asked by Ginsberg, behind the camera. After a fight scene, Ginsberg asks an unnamed friend in the shot whether the couple is fighting because the camera is on, to which the friend replies; “Oh I don’t think they’re doing it because the camera is on, but the camera's affecting them." In the WNET broadcast the two refer to the camera as a catalyst for action, and that their behavior in the presence of the camera was performance of only certain realities. The wedding itself is shot with more jump cuts, interviewing guests and featuring multiple close-up shots of details of the ceremony. The ceremony is a combination of a [[Jewish]] service and a media show, referencing [[Marshall Mcluhan]]'s [[the medium is the message]]. The wedding footages concludes with loud and obviously staged shots of the consummation of the marriage. In this footage the camera men are present and visible, the camera's whirring is recorded, and the camera men shout directions at the couple.<ref name="DVD">The Continuing Story of Carel and Ferd. Dir. Arthur Ginsberg. Video Data Bank: Surveying the First Decade Volume 1, 1972-5. DVD.</ref>
==Broadcast== The WNET program ran the video with the earlier black and white shots interspersed with later footage of [[Jon Carroll]], Ginsberg, Rowe, Eggan in a video studio, edited to seem as though they were watching and commenting on the earlier footage. The first instance of later footage is overlaid with scrolling text that introduces the program as it is being broadcast. The scrolling text introduction reads: "Video and Television Review brings you "The Continuing Story of Carel and Ferd", a documentary soap opera set in October 1970, when Carel Rowe and Ferd Eggan were about to "tie the knot" they invited a third partner to join the marriage, a portable video camera. Which for a while became the most demanding partner of all. For the next hour we join Carel and Ferd along with the tapemaker Arthur Ginsberg and Jon Carroll, the west coast editor of the Village Voice as they watch their story on tape again. It is a story about marriage, about sexual identity and about living too close to an electronic medium.”<ref name="DVD"/>
Though the footage was taken and presented before its appearance on public television, the WNET program ran after the original run of ''An American Family'' on PBS, linking the two as examples of precursors to reality television, early attempts at introducing the camera into daily life.
== References == {{Reflist}} <ref>Debbie Gould. http://areachicago.org/ferd-eggan-1946-2007/, Area Chicago: Ferd Eggan 1946-2007</ref> <ref>[http://www.vdb.org/titles/continuing-story-carel-and-ferd-excerpt Video Data Bank, The Continuing story of Carel and Ferd]</ref> <ref>http://www.eai.org/title.htm?id=2957 Electronic Arts Intermix, The Continuing story of Carel and Ferd</ref> <ref>Renov, Michael. "Video Confessions." The Subject of Documentary. Minneapolis: U of Minnesota, 2004. 201-02.</ref> <ref>Gary Indiana. http://www.poz.com/articles/221_1548.shtml. POZ, Inside Agitator</ref> <ref>Phillips, Glenn. "Arthur Ginsberg and Video Free America." California Video: Artists and Histories. Los Angeles: Getty Research Institute, 2008. 98-101.</ref> <ref>The Continuing Story of Carel and Ferd. Dir. Arthur Ginsberg. Video Data Bank: Surveying the First Decade Volume 1, 1972-5. DVD.</ref>

page.title: The Death of Major Peirson, 6 January 1781

revision.text:
{{Use British English|date=March 2012}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2013}} {{More footnotes|date=June 2011}} {{Infobox Artwork | image_file=John Singleton Copley 001.jpg | title=The Death of Major Peirson | artist=[[John Singleton Copley]] | year=1783 | medium=Oil-on-canvas | height_metric= | width_metric= | height_imperial= | width_imperial= | metric_unit=cm | imperial_unit=in | museum = [[Tate Britain]] }}
'''''The Death of Major Peirson, 6 January 1781''''' is a 1783 large [[oil painting]] by [[John Singleton Copley]]. It depicts the death of Major [[Francis Peirson]] at the [[Battle of Jersey]] on 6 January 1781.
The Battle of Jersey was the last French attempt to seize the island of [[Jersey]], and one of the last battles with invading forces from a foreign nation in the British home islands.<ref group="Note">The [[Battle of Culloden]] in 1746 was the last pitched battle on the British mainland; the [[Battle of Fishguard]] involved a short-lived French invasion of Wales in February 1797; and a French expeditionary force fought at the [[Battle of Ballinamuck]] in the [[Irish Rebellion of 1798]].</ref> The invasion was organised privately by Baron [[Philippe de Rullecourt]] but funded and supplied by the French government, and was intended to remove the threat that British naval vessel based in Jersey posed to American ships in the [[American Revolutionary War]].
Approximately 1,000 French soldiers, commanded by de Rullecourt and an Indian, [[Mir Sayyad]], landed at La Rocque, [[Grouville]], overnight on 5–6 January. They occupied [[St Helier]] early on the morning of 6 January. They captured the [[Lieutenant Governor of Jersey]], [[Moses Corbet]], in bed. Although Corbet surrendered, Peirson, the 24-year-old commander of around 2,000 troops of the British garrison, refused to surrender. As Peirson organised a counter-attack, a French shot killed him. Lieutenant Philippe Dumaresq of the Jersey militia took command of the British forces, which comprised detachments of the [[95th Regiment of Foot (1779)|95th Regiment of Foot]], [[72nd Regiment, Duke of Albany's Own Highlanders|78th<!--renumbered 72nd in 1786--> Highlanders]], and [[Jersey Militia]]. The British forces quickly overwhelmed the French, most of whom surrendered.
[[John Boydell]], a successful engraver and publisher and [[Aldermen]] of the [[City of London]], commissioned Copley to paint a large painting, {{convert|251.5|cm}} by {{convert|365.8|cm}}. The scene looks towards the final French resistance in [[Royal Square (Jersey)|Royal Square]], viewed along what is now Peirson Place, with the French soldiers taking their last stand around the statue of [[George II of Great Britain|George II]]. Further British reinforcements are visible on the hill at the top left. The statue and some of the buildings depicted still stand (some with bullet holes caused by the battle).
Although Peirson was killed in the early stages of the battle, the painting shows Peirson (at the centre of the painting under the large [[Union Flag]], supported by other officers) being shot down leading the final charge, giving him a more heroic role and fate. To the left, his black servant Pompey avenges his master by shooting the sniper. It is believed that the depictions of the officers supporting the stricken Peirson are true portraits; the black servant of auctioneer [[James Christie (auctioneer)|James Christie]] was the model for Pompey, although it is unclear whether a black servant played a role (there is no suggestion in contemporaneous sources). Copley modeled the civilians fleeing to the right on his wife, family nurse and children.
Peirson became a national hero, and the painting drew crowds when it was first exhibited at 28 [[Haymarket (London)|Haymarket]] in May 1784, with admission charged at 1 shilling. The [[Tate Gallery]] purchased the painting in 1864. Between 1989 and 2010, a copy appeared on the 10 [[Jersey pound]] note, and before that on the 1 pound note.

[[Image:Turesgrav.png|upright|thumb|The empty tomb of Ture Malmgren, 2015]]
The '''tomb of Ture Malmgren''' (referred to in Swedish as ''Tures grav'')<ref name="Hitta">{{cite web |url=http://tureborgen.blogspot.se/p/hitta-till-borgen.html |title=Hitta |language=Swedish |date=2014 |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |website=tureborgen.blogspot.se |publisher=Tureborg Society |access-date=22 April 2015}}</ref> is a structure located in [[Uddevalla]], [[Bohuslän]], Sweden. It is located by the foot of [[Fjällsätern]], near the center of the residential district of [[Tureborg (district)|Tureborg]] (which is named for [[Tureborg Castle]], a ruin atop the mountain's summit). [[Rock-cut architecture|Carved]] into the sheer cliff face, it was intended as the final resting place of the local politician and publicist [[Ture Malmgren]]. Despite his own wishes, Malmgren was instead interred elsewhere after his death in 1922, effectively rendering the empty [[rock-cut tomb]] a [[cenotaph]] of sorts.<ref name="Hansson2002">{{cite book |last=Hansson |first=Wilhelm |date=2002 |orig-year=First published 1968 |edition=3rd |title=Drömmarnas riddarborg |language=Swedish |location=[[Uddevalla]] |publisher=Villa Elfkullen Association |page=14 |access-date=22 April 2015 }}</ref>
==History== Ture Malmgren (born in 1851) is primarily known as the founder of the regional newspaper ''[[Bohusläningen]]'', which remains in publication today. Other than his career as a publicist and journalist, he maintained extensive business connections, and was involved in many fields of politics, often radical. Among other things, he was the first chairman of the [[Uddevalla Suffrage Association]], chaired the Uddevalla City Council for many years, and campaigned as a candidate for the [[Riksdag]]. In addition to these engagements he was also a keen builder, and constructed several large buildings.<ref>{{cite news |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date=1922 |title=Dödsruna över Ture Malmgren |newspaper=[[Bohusläningen]] |location=[[Uddevalla]] }}</ref> Of these, only [[Villa Elfkullen]] still stands – his large mock castle Tureborg burned down in 1950, and the faux-medieval summer residence [[Fjällhyddan]] was demolished later in the 20th century.<ref name="Hansson2002"/><ref>{{cite web |url=http://tureborgen.blogspot.se/p/blog-page.html |title=Fjällhyddan |language=Swedish |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date=2014 |website=www.tureborgen.blogspot.se |publisher=Tureborg Society |access-date=22 April 2015}}</ref>
Aside from these three main buildings, many other minor structures created by Malmgren are dotted around the surrounding landscape. One of these is a vaulted cavern cut into the grey rock of Fjällsätern at some point between the 1890s and the 1920s. Following his death on 3 August 1922, the local authorities decided against burying him in his intended final resting place, and instead he was buried at the nearby [[Eastern Cemetery (Uddevalla)|Eastern Cemetery]]. There, where he was joined by his wife [[Hilma Malmgren]] following her death in 1942, a large tombstone bearing his portrait was raised.<ref name="Hansson2002"/> The old tomb is now bricked up.<ref name="Hitta"/>

{{Other uses|Colorimeter (disambiguation){{!}}Colorimeter}} [[File:ColorHug2 - 03.jpg|thumb|Color calibration of a monitor using ColorHug2, an open source colorimeter, placed on the screen.]] A '''Tristimulus colorimeter''', colloquially shortened to colorimeter, is used in [[digital imaging]], to profile and calibrate output devices. It takes a limited number of wideband spectral energy readings along the [[visible spectrum]] by using [[optical filter|filtered]] [[photodetector]]s; e.g. [[silicon photodiode]]s.<ref name=schanda>{{cite book|last=Schanda|first=János|author2=George Eppeldauer |author3=Georg Sauter |title=Colorimetry: Understanding the CIE System|publisher=[[Wiley Interscience]]|date=2007|isbn=978-0-470-04904-4|chapter=Tristimulus Color Measurement of Self-Luminous Sources|doi=10.1002/9780470175637.ch6|editor=János Schanda}}</ref>
A colorimeter with the known value of absolute error allows measuring (x,y)-chromaticity coordinates in red, green, blue and white colors. Measured values are used for calculation of LCD profile coefficients.<ref>{{cite journal|url=http://ntv.ifmo.ru/en/article/13462/metod_programmnoy_kompensaciitehnologicheskogo_razbrosa_koordinat_cvetnostizhidkokristallicheskih_paneley.htm|title=Method of software-based compensation of technological variation in chromaticity coordinates of LCD panels|author=Zharinov I.O., Zharinov O.O.|journal=Scientific and Technical Journal of Information Technologies, Mechanics and Optics|volume=15|issue=3|pages=387–397|year=2015}}</ref>
Originally, three glass filters whose [[transmittance]] spectra mimicked the [[CIE 1931 color space|CIE]] [[color matching function]]s (shown below) were employed.<ref>{{cite journal|title=Photoelectric tristimulus colorimetry with three filters|journal=[[JOSA]]|first=Richard Sewall|last=Hunter|date=September 1942|volume=32|issue=9|pages=509–538| url=http://www.opticsinfobase.org/abstract.cfm?URI=josa-32-9-509|doi=10.1364/JOSA.32.000509}}</ref> A [[filter bank]] may be used to decompose the individual color matching functions if more accuracy is desired.<ref>{{cite journal|url=http://nvl.nist.gov/pub/nistpubs/jres/103/6/j36epp.pdf|format=PDF|title=Spectral Response Based Calibration Method of Tristimulus Colorimeters|first=George|last=Eppeldauer|journal=Journal of Research of the National Institute of Standards and Technology|volume=103|issue=6|date=Nov–Dec 1998|pages=615–619|doi=10.6028/jres.103.040|pmid=28009362|pmc=4890952}}</ref>
A camera or colorimeter is said to be ''colorimetric'' if it satisfies the {{Interlanguage link multi|Luther condition|de|3=Luther-Bedingung}} by {{Interlanguage link multi|Robert Thomas Dietrich Luther{{!}}Robert Luther|de|3=Robert Thomas Dietrich Luther}} (1868–1945)<!-- 1868-01-02 (21. December 1867 in Julian caldendar) to 1945-04-17, chemist --> (also called the "[[James Clerk Maxwell|Maxwell]]-[[Herbert E. Ives|Ives]] criterion"),<ref>{{cite journal|title=Aus dem Gebiet der Farbreizmetrik|last=Luther|first=Robert T.D.|authorlink=:de:Robert Thomas Dietrich Luther|date=1927|journal=Zeitschrift für technische Physik|volume=8|pages=540–558}}</ref> reducing [[metamerism (color)#Metameric failure|observer metamerism color errors]], if the product of the spectral responsivity of the photoreceptor and the spectral transmittance of the filters is a [[linear combination]] of the CMFs.<ref>{{cite book|title=Colorimetry|doi=10.1002/0470094745.ch5|page=154|first=Noboru|last=Ohta|author2=Robertson, Alan R. |isbn=978-0-470-09472-3|chapter=Measurement and Calculation of Colorimetric Values|date=2005|publisher=John Wiley & Sons, Ltd.}}</ref>
A colorimeter or a digital camera with a [[color filter array]] can, under certain conditions, be used as an alternative to a [[spectrophotometer]].<ref name=Imai1999>{{cite journal | author = Imai, Francisco H. |author2=Berns, Roy S. | date = 1999 | title = Spectral estimation using trichromatic digital cameras | journal = Proceedings of the International Symposium on Multispectral Imaging and Color Reproduction for Digital Archives | volume = 42 | url = http://www.cis.rit.edu/research/mcsl2/online/Spectral/TechnicalPapers/SpecEstimRGBCamera_Chiba99.pdf |format=PDF| accessdate = 2008-05-06 }}</ref><ref name=Solli2004>{{cite journal | last = Solli | first = Martin |date=16 December 2004 | title = Filter characterization in digital cameras | url = http://www.diva-portal.org/diva/getDocument?urn_nbn_se_liu_diva-2667-1__fulltext.pdf |format=PDF| accessdate = 2008-05-06 }}</ref>
The [[standard illuminant|illuminant]] and [[CIE 1931 color space#CIE standard observer|observer conditions]] should be specified when citing a measurement (e.g. [[CIE Standard Illuminant D65|D65]]/10°).<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=oEsZiCt5VOAC&pg=PA42&dq=%22tristimulus+colorimeter%22+OR+spectrocolorimeter#PPA41,M1|title=The Colour Image Processing Handbook|first=Stephen J.|last=Sangwine|author2=Horne |author3=Robin E. N. |page=41|publisher=[[Springer Science+Business Media|Springer]]|date=1998|isbn=0-412-80620-7}}</ref>
The quality of a colorimeter may be assessed using the means in CIE publication 179:2007.<ref>{{cite book|title=Methods for characterising tristimulus colorimeters for measuring the colour of light|author=CIE TC 2-16 "Characterization of the Performance of Tristimulus Colorimeters"|isbn=978-3-901906-60-2|series=Publication 179:2007|date=2007|url=http://www.cie.co.at/publ/abst/179-07.html|publisher=CIE Central Bureau|location=Vienna}}</ref>
There are various calibration methods for tristimulus colorimeters.<ref>{{cite journal | last = Gardner | first = James L. | title = Comparison of Calibration Methods for Tristimulus Colorimeters | journal = Journal of Research of the National Institutes of Standards and Technology | volume = 112 | issue = 3 | pages = 129–138 | date = May–June 2007 | url = http://nvl.nist.gov/pub/nistpubs/jres/112/3/V112.N03.A01.pdf | doi = 10.6028/jres.112.010 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080528051448/http://nvl.nist.gov/pub/nistpubs/jres/112/3/V112.N03.A01.pdf | archivedate = 2008-05-28 | df = }}</ref>
